data.text: Carbon Belt and a Gear Hub for Long-Distance Touring

What are people's views on a carbon belt and a gear hub...seem to be very durable, but no experience of using them. Just wonder how reliable they are and what the chances of them gettin fixed if I'm far away from home?

I use one. Never did any maintenance and it's still good as new. If the belt brakes you need to replace it, but that's really rare. You can carry a spare though. Hubs like the Rholoff are essentially indestructible outside of actual trauma.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: I use one on a Surly ECR - it truly is the best thing since sliced bread. I have never had any problems, even with the bike covered in mud for days.
data.author: √û√≥r√∞ur √ìlafur √û√≥r√∞arson

data.text: Never had an issue and never maintained.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: Use my Priority Continuum (enviolo + carbon belt) under harsh conditions (-25c, salt and slush) and its beyond my expectations.
data.author: Richard Aub√©

data.text: Only 2k kms on my belt/rohloff, and I‚Äôve still not really got used to the differences with my old chain/derailer system. Beautiful not having to maintain a chain and cogs every day-or several times a day when it‚Äôs wet, but I really miss the old feel of a steel chain shifting gears.. And the irritating gear 7 on the rohloff! It‚Äôs become my arch enemy on the rd.
data.author: Paul Agnew

data.text: yeah, i normally find an excuse to go to 6 or 8.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: mine got much quieter after I got the oil changed.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: Mine was secondhand so I've no idea how many miles it's done, I've done about 100 miles and barely notice the 7th gear whine.
data.author: Chris Pine

data.text: They don‚Äôt break You will break before they do. Don‚Äôt worry
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: Correct. If one wonders about the durability of the belt, think of the belts in your car. How often do they fail?
data.author: Bill Bacon

data.text: They do if you install them incorrectly - Ryan Duzer had a failure once cos of that..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Normally I wouldn't chuck a bucket of mud under my car bonnet but I get your point üôÇ
data.author: Chris Pine

data.text: that‚Äôs not the components fault!
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: Sigh.. I didn‚Äôt say it was did I?.. you said they don‚Äôt break - they can and do..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: I guess ya can‚Äôt fix stooopid!!
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: Thanks all...do you find the gears are suited to climbing? Just thinking the limited gears may make hills a struggle?
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: that depends on your setup. For one, you can swap external gears. Also, my 14 speed rholoff has a wider gear range than a touring 3x10, with a slighyly lower granny gear (20" vs 22")
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: Also a 14 speed hub actually has essentially the same gear jumps as a 3x10. So many gears overlap due to the changes on the front chainring.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: If you really want a super range, which you probably won't need, try the pinion 18-speed.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: gear range is so wide. Absolutely no problem. Even on very steep hills. I've got a 50/22 belt on a Rohloff. You can always go smaller if needed. But I doubt it.
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: There have been some climbs that are too steep to traverse. However those are really rare and I don't think any US road would allow that steepness (mostly forest trails, etc). A lot depends on your weight both of yourself and the cargo you carry. If you are a large, strong person, like myself, you need a wider gearing as gravity affects me more on the hills, but isn't a concern for the flats. If you are a smaller person without much cargo, you can be fine with a narrower gear range.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text:
Take a look at the analyses from Alee Denham. He has some really in-depth content from someone who basically just tours and gets money from posting on YouTube about touring. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SKeQ6B2UTk
Belts Are The BEST Bicycle Drivetrain Available (Epic Testing!)
youtube.com

data.text: The belt kept going without a problem, even though it rubbed against the hard mud.
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: I have a Rohloff hub with electric shift and it‚Äôs sweet and virtually indestructible.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: can you give me a link or is this on an e-bike?

data.text:
mine is on an ebike but it works on any bike. https://www.cyclingabout.com/tour-with-a-rohloff-hub/
16 Reasons To Tour With A Rohloff Hub (And 9 Reasons To Not) - CyclingAbout
cyclingabout.com
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: 20K+ kms and not one issue. Wouldn‚Äôt go back to a chain and derailer again.
data.author: Ben Storer

data.text: I use a Rohloff, although building my bike in 2007 before the carbon belts came about I use a KMC bmx chain which removes in seconds & cleans in petrol from my stove's fuel bottle, also my chainring is stainless (Surly) so never wears out. Over three tours my hub's done 96,000 km without any problems.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Deleted
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: Oh of course, but relative to that of typical aluminium, it's negligible. England to Cape Town & England to Singapore on the same, 44 tooth chainring.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: With the second generation center track belts you can expect to get (according to Gates) up to 50k before replacement. Chains about 6k. Belts are close to maintenance free, lighter in weight, quiet, about as efficient as chains and not greasy. All in all, superior for touring if you‚Äôre able to use an internal gear hub.
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: Chain a day long. You can buy one to suit in any bike shop on the planet.
data.author: Adrian Dunne

data.text: you can order a belt from the internet and it stores both light and easy
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: I've got 2 Rohloff bikes, one with chain, one with belt. If I had to buy again, I'd always go for belt.
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: - I could not agree more!
data.author: √û√≥r√∞ur √ìlafur √û√≥r√∞arson

data.text: About the belt: if it makes noise, add some drops of shampoo. Cogs: I use larger ones with spider, so if the belt would break, I could at least use a chain with chain rings. Yes, they are made of aluminium instead of steel. But the increased number of teeth compensate the softer material (at >17‚Äô000km and haven‚Äôt got to the half I think) Rohloff: it had not enough development for me. Which is why I went for pinion.eu. I would nowadays consider rohloff with SchlumpfDrive to get over 800% development For those who don‚Äôt have an opening for the belt, there is a solution: www.veercycle.com
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: I found the veer belt yesterday, I have a Rohloff and can now fit belt drive as the veer belt splits.
data.author: Chris Pine

data.text: I guess many of us would love your feedback! üçÄüçªüçªü§ì
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: I‚Äôve never ever seen a bicycle shop stock spare belts or belt cogs, but they always stock chains and cassettes.
data.author: William Griggs

data.text: Good luck on finding a Rohloff cog in a bikeshop. Just don't worry, belts don't break.
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: lol
data.author: Derek Mann

data.text: I have a Gates carbon belt and Rohloff speedhub on my Koga WorldTraveller-S and wouldn‚Äôt entertain going back to a chain and derailleur. They are absolutely fantastic!!
data.author: Bob Taylor

data.text: Koga builds a killer bike !
data.author: Derek Mann

data.text: Gates and Pinion!
data.author: Derek Mann

data.text: Have had 1 belt break after 33.000k so if you put a new one on or buy a new bike before a tour with a belt and rohloff get some 4 piston hydraulic disc brakes with toolless pad adjusment and bite adjustment and your set for at least 5.000km before a oil change on the rohloff
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I would love one.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I have 2 bikes with a Gates belt and Pinion 1.18: one with over 40000 km, one with about 15000 km: zero problems.
data.author: Guido Vervoort

data.text: I love mine ,The noise in 7 doesn't bother me at all & it's quite anyway , Now the clunks my SRAM 1 x12 made every time I changed gear drove me mad doing LEJOG .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: the bike I'm looking at has the Shimano 8 internal gears...just unsure if that would have enough range for something like LEJOG, which I've done on my current hybrid bike with normal chain.
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: If budget allows I'd go for a Rohloff ,Thorn bikes forum have a for sale section of well looked after bikes , I did LEJOG on a SRAM 1 x12 mainly off road & I found Cornwall hard ..The Rohloff has a slightly better ratio ,plus you can always change the front chain drive up or down .I love the fact that I don't have to keep tweaking / cleaning the gears to run properly .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: I think Cornwall would be hard on an e bikeüòÄ...will check out that forum.
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: I‚Äôd be more concerned with the shifter. 18 months with the pinion and already had to rerun the cables. Luckily,I found someone with some shifter knowledge in central France. However, he was only able to restore 12 of the 18 gears.
data.author: Eddie Aceves
